text: let's update you now on a developing
story out of Hong Kong we are hearing
reports that leader Carrie Lam is to
formally withdraw a proposed extradition
bill that has sparked three months of
process the top market bear has surged
on the news this bill would have allowed
Hong Kong citizens to be sent to
mainland China to face trial and in the
last few minutes other news coming out
of Hong Kong as well is that Cathay
Pacific the airline have announced that
its chairman john Schlosser has resigned
now you'll know that Cathay Pacific has
been caught up in the process when some
of its staff were fired for supporting
them
let's take you straight to Steve
mcdonald who joins me now from Hong Kong
firstly to this news that Carrie Lam is
going to be potentially withdrawing the
extradition bill is that for sure Steve
do we know well it's not for sure that a
lot of people think that is what's going
to happen there are a lot of leaks
coming out of the government Carrie Lam
is having a meeting with the pro-beijing
camp in the Legislative Council and also
members Hong Kong members of the
National People's Congress that's the
Chinese Parliament and after that
meeting she's expected to come out and
make an announcement that this bill is
now officially dead now if that is the
case of its completely withdrawn this
will be a humiliating back down for her
administration and also for Beijing it's
been one of the key demands of the
protest movement and it's seen as
something of an olive branch an attempt
to try and take the heat out of this
crisis which now in its third month is
seeing these regular violent street
clashes between radicalized protesters
and riot police the problem though is
that the longer this has taken to solve
the broader the protester demands have
become and so already on these chat
rooms the pro-democracy activists are
saying will will this be enough for us
after all this is only one of our five
demands now other things they want is an
inquiry and independent inquiry into
alleged police links with organized
crime and police behavior
there's something that the government
said it won't do it they want universal
suffrage no of course that's a long way
down the track it would take quite
something for Beijing to agree to that
however this was what started it this
whole movement started because of this
opposition to is very unpopular
extradition bill allowing for people to
be sent potentially to courts on the

they had to have sacked many staff and
the chairman has now joined the CEO in
